quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 11: Unit 7 Quiz 1
quiz.subtitle: 7.1: Mole and Avogadro's Number Review and Extension
quiz.subject: Chemistry

questions.question: What is the numerical value of Avogadro's number?
questions.explanation: Avogadro's number ($N_A$) represents the number of particles in exactly one mole of a substance.

questions.question: The 'Mole' is defined as the number of atoms in exactly $12$ grams of which isotope?
questions.explanation: The SI base unit for amount of substance is based on the carbon-12 isotope as the standard.

questions.question: How many atoms of gold are in $1.00$ mole of gold?
questions.explanation: One mole of any substance contains Avogadro's number of representative particles, whether they are atoms, molecules, or ions.

questions.question: If you have $2.00$ moles of $H_2O$ molecules, how many total ATOMS do you have?
questions.explanation: One molecule of $H_2O$ has 3 atoms. $2$ moles of molecules $\times 3$ atoms/molecule $\times 6.022 \times 10^{23}$ atoms/mole $= 3.61 \times 10^{24}$ atoms.

questions.question: Which of the following contains the same number of particles as $1.0$ mole of $NH_3$?
questions.explanation: A mole is a fixed count. $1.0$ mole of any substance contains the same number of units ($6.022 \times 10^{23}$) as $1.0$ mole of any other substance.

questions.question: To convert from 'Number of Particles' to 'Number of Moles', you should:
questions.explanation: Moles $= \frac{\text{Particles}}{6.022 \times 10^{23}}$. Division scales the large count down to the mole unit.

questions.question: A sample contains $3.011 \times 10^{23}$ molecules of $CO_2$. How many moles is this?
Why is the mole used as a counting unit instead of just counting individual atoms?
options: Atoms are too small to count individually in a laboratory setting
The mole is more accurate than individual counting
The mole only applies to gases
Individual atoms do not have mass
questions.explanation: The mole bridges the gap between the submicroscopic world of atoms and the macroscopic world of the laboratory.

questions.question: How many moles of oxygen atoms are in $1.0$ mole of $Ca_3(PO_4)_2$?
questions.explanation: In the formula $Ca_3(PO_4)_2$, there are $2 \times 4 = 8$ oxygen atoms per formula unit.

questions.question: Which has a greater number of moles: $6.022 \times 10^{23}$ atoms of Lead or $6.022 \times 10^{23}$ atoms of Helium?
options: They have the same number of moles
questions.explanation: Both represent exactly $1.0$ mole, even though lead atoms are much heavier than helium atoms.

scoreMessages.90: Mole Master! You have a perfect grasp of Avogadro's constant.
scoreMessages.70: Great job. You're counting particles like a pro.
scoreMessages.50: Good effort. Remember that $1$ mole always equals $6.022 \times 10^{23}$ particles.
scoreMessages.0: Review the definition of the mole and how to convert particles to moles.
